title-group.article-title: Anti-genotoxic role of eicosapentaenoic acid against imazalil-induced DNA damage in vitro

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Molecular Biology and Genetics, Faculty of Sciences, Erzurum Technical University, Turkey
2Department of Biology, Faculty of Sciences, Atatürk University, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Elanur Aydin, Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Atatürk University, 25240 Erzurum, Turkey. Email: elanuraydinn@gmail.com

abstract.p: Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) is a polyunsaturated n-3 fatty acid and is essential to the health of mammals. Recent data show that EPA can act as anti-mutagenic agent. On the other hand, pesticides comprise a new and important class of environmental pollutants nowadays. Imazalil (IMA), a commonly used fungicide in both agricultural and clinical domains is suspected to produce very serious toxic effects in vertebrates. The present study investigated the anti-genotoxic effect of EPA against the genotoxic damage induced by IMA on cultured human lymphocytes using chromosomal aberration (CA) and micronucleus (MN) tests as cytogenetic endpoints. Peripheral blood cells were treated in vitro with varying concentrations of EPA (2.5, 5, 10, 20 and 40 μg/ml), tested in combination with IMA (336 μg/ml). Our results revealed that the rates of CAs and MNs in lymphocytes were significantly (p < 0.05) increased by IMA as compared to the controls. The results also showed that EPA alone was not genotoxic. Moreover, when combined with IMA treatment, EPA reduced the frequencies of CAs and MNs. A clear dose-dependent decrease in the genotoxic damage of IMA was observed, suggesting a genoprotective role of EPA. In conclusion, our data may have an important application for the protection of cultured human lymphocyte from the genetic damage and repercussions induced by agricultural and industrial chemicals hazardous in people.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) have an important role in human diet, both for the prevention and the therapy of different pathologies (La Guardia et al., 2005). This therapeutic and health promoting role of highly unsaturated PUFAs from fish, that is eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA, 20:5n-3), is well known (Cequier-Sanchez et al., 2011). PUFAs were effective on diverse pathological processes impacting chronic disease, such as cardiovascular and immune disease, neurological disease and cancer (Katić et al., 2010; Notarnicola et al., 2011). Chemical composition and biological activities of PUFAs have long been investigated for antitumor (Lim et al., 2009), antiproliferative (Slagsvold et al., 2009), anti-inflammatory (Ohtsuka et al., 2011), antioxidant (Safarinejad, 2011), antiobesity (Sato et al., 2010) and anticancer (Giros et al., 2009) properties. Bartsch et al. (1999) reported that ω-3 fatty acids (EPA and docosahexaenoic acid) have been shown to inhibit tumor cell proliferation. Besides, recent findings indicated that essential fatty acids including EPA could act as anti-mutagenic agent (Manna et al., 2010; Ponnala et al., 2009).

Imazalil (C14H14Cl2N2O; IMA) is a fungicide that is extensively used in fruit plantations and post-harvest treatments but has teratogenic effects on vertebrate development (Zega et al., 2009). The common use of pesticides in the agricultural industry to control the insects, pests and fungus and to enhance the crop and fruit production is recognized as a major chemical health hazard for the orchard workers, residents and children by direct contact and by polluting the aerial, soil and water environment (Bhat et al., 2010). IMA is suspected to produce craniofacial malformations in vertebrates, although very scarce data are available about its genotoxicity. The only two investigations on IMA genotoxicity clearly indicated that the fungicide induced significant DNA damage in a dose-dependent manner (Sisman and Türkez, 2010; Vindas et al., 2004). It was also reported that IMA produced some adverse effects in reproductive and neurobehavioral parameters in mice (Pennati et al., 2006; Tanaka, 1995). In brief, the contemporaneous exposure to IMA or its therapeutic use was considered potentially dangerous for humans (Menegola et al., 2006).

In recent years, a great deal of effort has been made to investigate the therapeutic substances that are capable of reducing the genotoxicity of various natural and man-made mutagens in human life (Turkez and Geyikoglu, 2010a). These include PUFAs, vitamins, sulfhydryl substances and plant products (Cockbain et al., 2012; Edenharder et al., 1999; Rao et al., 2001). Concomitant treatment with the antioxidants with mutagens provided protection against tissue damages in experimental models (Abubakar et al., 2003; Esparza et al., 2003; Turkez and Aydin, in press; Turkez and Dirican, in press; Turkez et al., 2010, in press; Turkez and Geyikoglu, 2010a, b). To our best knowledge, there is no recorded data on the role of EPA against IMA-induced cytogenetic damage in cultured human blood cells as a cellular model for genotoxicity testing. Therefore, the aim of the present study was to assess the potential beneficial role of EPA on IMA-induced genotoxicity. For this aim, we assessed the frequencies of chromosomal aberrations (CAs) and micronuclei (MNs) in cultured human lymphocytes following treatments with EPA and IMA. In fact, CA and MN are inexpensive, rapid and sensitive tests for evaluating the presence and extent of DNA damage in human populations that are exposed to genotoxic substances in environments and lifestyles (Guneshwor et al., 2007; Turkez and Geyikoglu, 2010).

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: The heparinized blood samples from six healthy nonsmoking donors between the age 26 and 28 with no history of exposure to any genotoxic agent was used in our experiments. Questionnaires were obtained for each blood donor to evaluate exposure history and, in addition, informed consent forms were signed by each donor. In all the volunteers involved in this study, hematological and biochemical parameters were analyzed and no pathology was detected. The fungicide IMA (1-[2-(2,4-dichlorophenyl)-2-(2-propenyloxy) ethyl]-1H-imidazole sulfate, CAS No. 58594-72-2) and EPA (C20H30O2, CAS No. 10417-94-4) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich® (St Louis, Missouri, USA). IMA (at 336 μg/ml) and various concentrations (2.5, 5, 10, 20 and 40 μg/ml) of EPA were tested in cultured human lymphocytes. These compounds were added to the cultures just before incubation for cytogenetic analysis. The studies have been approved by the appropriate local committees and have been performed according to the Declaration of Helsinki. The investigation stems (dose selection) from the previous works (Bechoua et al., 1999; Sisman and Turkez, 2010; Vindas et al., 2004). After supplementation of IMA and EPA, the blood was incubated for 72 h at 37°C to adjust body conditions for testing CA and MN formations.

sec.title: CA assay
sec.p: Human peripheral blood lymphocyte cultures were set up according to the protocol described by Evans and O’Riordan (1975) with a slight modification. A 0.5 ml aliquot of heparinized blood was cultured in 6 ml of culture medium (Chromosome Medium B; Biochrom®, Berlin) with 5 mg/ml of phytohemagglutinin (Biochrom). The cultures were incubated in complete darkness for 72 h at 37°C. Two hours prior to harvesting, 0.1 ml of colchicine (0.2 mg/ml, Sigma®) was added to the culture flask. Hypotonic treatment and fixation were performed. To prepare slides, 3–5 drops of the fixed cell suspension were dropped on a clean slide and air-dried. The slides were stained in 3% Giemsa solution in phosphate buffer (pH 6.8) for 15 min. For each treatment, 30 well-spreaded metaphases were analyzed to detect the presence of CAs. Criteria to classify the different types of aberrations (chromatid or chromosome gap and chromatid or chromosome break) were in accordance with the recommendation of Environmental Health Criteria 46 for environmental monitoring of human populations (IPCS, 1985).

sec.title: MN assay
sec.p: The MN test was performed by adding cytochalasin B (Sigma®) after 44 h of culture as previously described by Fenech and Morley (1985). At the end of the incubation period, the lymphocytes were fixed with ice-cold methanol:acetic acid (1:1). The fixed cells were put directly on slides using a cytospin and stained with May Grünwald-Giemsa. All slides were coded before scoring. The slides were scored according to criteria reported by Fenech (1993). At least 2000 binucleated lymphocytes were examined per concentration (two cultures per concentration) for the presence of one, two or more micronuclei.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: The results are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. Comparison between groups was carried out by one-way analysis of variance followed by Duncan multiple range test with the level of significance set at p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The effects of IMA and EPA on the number CAs and MNs in human whole blood cultures are shown in Figures 1 and 2, respectively. IMA (336 μg/ml) caused significant increases in CA and MN frequencies in human peripheral lymphocytes compared with the controls. The results showed that EPA at all applied concentrations did not indicate significant differences (p < 0.05) in the number of CAs and MNs statistically. Moreover, the positive effects of EPA were established on IMA-induced CA and MN formations. And the incidences of these end points were decreased in comparison with IMA-alone-treated group. Also, this situation was related as depending on the concentrations of EPA.

caption.p: Chromosome aberration rates in human peripheral lymphocytes treated with EPA, IMA and their combinations. (Values are expressed as means for six cultures in each group. **Symbol means statistically significant differences at p < 0.05 level from the control group. IMA: 336 μg/ml of imazalil; EPA 1: 2.5 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid; EPA 2: 5 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid; EPA 3: 10 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid; EPA 4: 20 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid; EPA 5: 40 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid.).

Micronucleus (MN) frequencies (‰) in human peripheral lymphocytes treated with EPA, IMA and their combinations. (Values are expressed as means of six cultures in each group. **Symbol means statistically significant differences at p < 0.05 level from the control group. IMA: 336 μg/ml of imazalil; EPA 1: 2.5 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid; EPA 2: 5 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid; EPA 3: 10 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid; EPA 4: 20 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid; EPA 5: 40 μg/ml of eicosapentaenoic acid.).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The concern about pesticide residues in and on food and about the environmental impact has been growing. The review of available literature indicated that many pesticides enhance the oxidative stress in organisms, and such stress might be linked to developmental alterations, including reproductive effects, embryotoxicity and/or teratogenicity (Pašková et al., 2011). The mutagenic and clastogenic chemicals caused teratogenic and/or carcinogenic effects (Babich et al., 1985). Also, it was reported that pesticides could cause gene mutations and CAs in exposed individuals (Titlić et al., 2007). The results of this study indicated that IMA caused DNA damages in lymphocytes, because dose-dependent increases in MN and CA frequencies were observed in IMA-treated cultures. In fact, CA test is regarded as a very important and useful indicator of exposure to biological and chemical agents (Padovani et al., 1997). MN assay provides a measure of both chromosome breakage and chromosome loss or non-disjunction in clastogenic and aneugenic events, respectively (Karaman et al., 2009). And damaged DNA can lead to aneuploidy and/or chromosomal instability, which is believed to be the major contributor to tumor progression (Erol, 2010). This finding is supported by other investigators. As a matter of fact, Vindas et al. (2004) detected the single-strand breaks in DNA and alkali-labile sites by comet assay in cultured human lymphocytes and reported that IMA caused DNA damage. IMA-induced genotoxicity in humans was also reported by Ramirez and Cuenca (2002). Likewise, IMA caused increases in the frequencies of the CAs and the rates of MN as compared to controls in a dose-dependent manner (Sisman and Turkez, 2010). However, there are also contradictory findings on the mutagenicity of IMA (Thienpont et al., 1981).

Nakagawa and Moore (1995) found that addition of IMA to suspensions of isolated rat hepatocytes caused cell death accompanied by depletion of intracellular glutathione and protein thiols, with accumulation of intracellular malondialdehyde (an end product of lipid peroxidation). So the genotoxic effects of IMA that were observed in this study could be explained in relation with its oxidative damage potential. At this point, we also suggest that EPA could have important biological and pharmaceutical consequences, because IMA-induced CA and MN formations in our study were also ameliorated by concurrent administration of EPA. As a matter of fact, EPA supplementation decreased the product levels of lipid peroxidation (4-hydroxy-2-nonenal) and oxidative DNA damage (8-hydoxy-deoxyguanosine) in diabetic mice (Taneda et al., 2010). EPA protected cells by scavenging superoxide radicals mediated by superoxide dismutase enzyme production (Sohma et al., 2007). Thus, the observed anti-genotoxic effect of EPA in this study could be clearly attributed to its antioxidative activity. So EPA modulated the cyclophosphamide (a genuine mutagenic agent)-induced genotoxic damage via preventing oxidative stress in mice (Li et al., 2011). EPA reduced the number of MN containing lymphocytes when tested in combination with phenytoin sodium/diphenyl hydantoin (a well-known mutagen) but produced insignificant increase in the amount of genetic damage when tested alone (Ponnala et al., 2009). Again, Ozyurt et al. (2007) evaluated the effects of EPA against oxidative DNA damage in MK-801-induced rat experimental psychosis model by determining the enzyme activities of xanthine oxidase (XO) and adenosine deaminase (AD) as indicators of DNA oxidation. Their results showed that the XO and AD enzyme activities were significantly decreased in EPA plus MK-801 treated rats, when compared to MK-801 group.

As a result, the most probable mechanism of DNA damage by IMA seems to be through the oxidative stress. And the present investigation indicates that EPA has a genoprotective capability on IMA-induced genotoxic damage. This evidence can have an important application for the protection of human lymphocytes from the genotoxic damages induced by agricultural and industrial chemicals hazardous in people.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The authors are grateful to volunteers for the blood samples.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
